Yes, the Port-Royal Grammar, Immanuel Kant, August Schleicher, and Gottlob Frege made significant contributions to the theories of studying word meanings. Here is a brief overview of their contributions:

1. Port-Royal Grammar: The Port-Royal Grammar, authored by Antoine Arnauld and Claude Lancelot in the 17th century, was an influential work in linguistics and the study of language. It aimed to provide a rational basis for grammar and emphasized the importance of logic and reasoning in understanding language. The authors focused on the relationship between syntax, semantics, and the logical structure of sentences, arguing that meaning is derived from the relationships between words in a sentence. This work laid the foundation for later theories of generative grammar and formal semantics.
2. Immanuel Kant: Immanuel Kant, an 18th-century German philosopher, made important contributions to the understanding of word meanings in his work, "The Critique of Pure Reason." He posited that meaning is a product of the interaction between our innate mental structures (categories) and our sensory experiences. According to Kant, our understanding of the world is shaped by these categories, which provide the basis for our ability to make sense of our experiences and give meaning to the words we use to describe them.
3. August Schleicher: August Schleicher was a 19th-century German linguist who contributed to the study of word meanings through his work on historical and comparative linguistics. He developed the idea of language families, proposing that languages evolve over time through a process of change and divergence, similar to the evolution of species in biology. Schleicher's work helped to establish the field of historical linguistics and showed how the meanings of words can change over time as languages evolve.
4. Gottlob Frege: Gottlob Frege was a 19th-century German philosopher, logician, and mathematician who made significant contributions to the study of word meanings through his work on logic and the philosophy of language. In his work "On Sense and Reference," Frege argued that the meaning of a word or expression is not merely its reference (the object it refers to) but also its sense (the way it presents the object). This distinction between sense and reference has had a lasting impact on the study of meaning in both philosophy and linguistics, influencing later theories of semantics and the development of formal logic.

These thinkers, along with others mentioned previously, have contributed to the rich tapestry of theories and ideas that have shaped our understanding of word meanings and the ways in which language functions to convey meaning.
